HCMG 890 examines issues related to managing or investing in Health Care Services Businesses. Defined as companies that manage, distribute or provide health care services, the Health Care Services sector touches almost every other portion of the health care system. We will study the key management issues related to a number of different health care services businesses with a focus on common challenges related to reimbursement, regulatory, margin, growth, and competitive issues. We will make extensive use of outside speakers who will all be current industry leaders within different sectors of the health care services industry and will address the current management issues they face in running their businesses. We will also hear Private Equity professionals and people involved legislatively in Washington with health care services. Students will then be asked to develop a plan to both buyout and subsequently manage a specific health care services business. Students will present their plans to a panel of leading Health Care Private Equity investors.

Students, as a whole, loved this course. They thought it was “one of the most practical course they took at Wharton” and some even went as far as to say it was the “best course they had taken at college.” Everyone also agreed that the guest speakers that were brought in were absolutely “phenomenal and insightful.”

Students felt that they learned a great deal from Professor Present. They thought that he was “an excellent professor and good at motivating and communicating with the class.” Even though he is very busy, students thought that Professor Present made time to talk to students who had questions or were seeking career advice.

There were not many complaints on the difficulty of the course. Most students liked that they got the opportunity to present to real private equity investors while some felt that “they could use a more helpful guide as a template for these presentations.”

Students felt that this course “provided a good introduction to medical devices” but sometimes lacked basic assumptions that were needed to understand the material fully. A lot of students would recommend this course to their friends and they thought the guest speakers “gave very insightful and stimulating presentations.”

Professor Solomon was a good professor, although he did not spend a lot of time lecturing. Students liked that he also incorporated “real world events” because it made it a lot more interesting. 

As far as coursework is concerned, students felt that there was too much reading necessary. Some also did not like that the grade breakdown was very “all-or-nothing.” Also, some students did not like the “randomly assigned cross-functional groups.”
